revision.text:
The '''Kitab al Miraj''' (Arabic: كتاب المعراج "Book of the Ascension") is a [[Islam|Muslim]] book concerned with [[Muhammad]]'s ascension into [[Heaven]] (known as the ''[[Isra and Mi'raj|Miraj]]''), following his miraculous one-night journey from [[Mecca]] to [[Jerusalem]] (the ''Isra''). The book is divided into 7 chapters, and was written in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] using the [[Naskh (script)|Naskh script]].
Kitab al-Miraj is believed to have been written by Abu'l-Qasim 'Abdalkarîm bin Hawâzin bin 'Abdalmalik bin Talhah bin Muhammad al-Qushairî al-Nisaburi أبو القاسم عبد الكريم بن هوازن بن عبد الملك بن طلحة بن محمد القشيري (born 376 [[Hijri year|A.H.]]/ 986 [[Common Era|CE]] - died 465 [[Hijri year|A.H.]]/ 1072 [[Common Era|CE]]).
In the second half of the 13th century, the book was translated into [[Latin]] (as ''Liber Scale Machometi'') and [[Spanish language|Spanish]], and soon thereafter (in 1264 [[Common Era|CE]]) into [[Old French]].<ref>I. Heullant-Donat and M.-A. Polo de Beaulieu, "Histoire d'une traduction," in ''Le Livre de l'échelle de Mahomet'', translated by Gisèle Besson and Michèle Brossard-Dandré, Collection ''Lettres Gothiques'', Le Livre de Poche, 1991, p. 22.</ref> Its Islamic depictions of [[Hell]] are believed by some scholars to have been a major influence on [[Dante Alighieri|Dante]]'s (born 1265 [[Common Era|CE]] - died 1321 [[Common Era|CE]]) 14th century masterpiece, the [[Divine Comedy]] (completed in 1320), including [[Miguel Asín Palacios]], and [[Enrico Cerulli]] .
==See also== *[[Isra and Mi'raj]] *[[Divine Comedy]]
==Notes== {{reflist}}
==References== *[http://www.soufisme.org/site/article.php3?id_article=33 Traces de soufisme en Europe occidentale] *[http://kblibrary.bih.nic.in/Vol15/Bp040.htm Bibliographic reference to the Miraj from Khuda Bakhsh Library in Patna, India] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080319003125/http://www20.brinkster.com/gurupak/Miraaj%20-%20The%20Ascension%20to%20Heaven.htm THE NIGHT JOURNEY OF MUHAMMAD TO HEAVEN]
[[Category:Sunni literature]] [[Category:Medieval Arabic literature]] [[Category:Entering Heaven alive]]

{{LGBT mythology mini}} [[Chinese mythology]] has been described as "rich in stories about homosexuality", reflecting ancient Chinese perspectives toward variance in sexuality and gender, rather than modern views. Chinese myths and traditional folk tales are greatly influenced by religious beliefs, particularly [[Taoist]], [[Confucian]], and [[Buddhist]].
Myths include instances of changing gender and sexual activity between members of the same sex, or between humans and supernatural creatures that assume a form of the same sex.
==Sexuality in Chinese myths== [[Image:Eight Immortals Crossing the Sea - Project Gutenberg eText 15250.jpg|thumbnail|right|250px|"The [[Eight Immortals]] Crossing the Sea", from ''Myths and Legends of China'', 1922, E.T.C. Werner.]] [[Chinese mythology]] has been described as "rich in stories about homosexuality".<ref name=GLBTQchinese1>Xiaomingxiong (2002), p.1</ref> The mythological stories and folklore of China reflect ancient Chinese perspectives toward homosexuality, rather than modern views. These myths are greatly influenced by religious beliefs, particularly [[Taoist]] and [[Confucian]], and later incorporated [[Buddhist]] teachings.<ref name=GLBTQchinese1/> Homosexuality in Chinese myths or folk tales may involve explicit physical contact, but may also be represented by more "profound emotions and feelings", making it difficult to unambiguously differentiate a homoerotic relationship from other social relationships, such as a friendship or rivalry.<ref>Louie (2002), p. 24</ref> Sexual activity in Chinese myth is often described metaphorically, for example, in military terms. This leads some readers to interpret scenes of combat figuratively, as sexual metaphors. Popular folk stories are generally more explicit about same-sex romantic encounters than later literary re-tellings.<ref name=Louie25>Louie (2002), p. 25</ref> Male and female homosexuality were considered to be unrelated in ancient China, and there are very few descriptions of lesbianism in traditional Chinese texts.<ref>[[Ruan Fangfu|Ruan, Fang Fu]] and Bullough, Vern L; ''Lesbianism in China'', Archives of Sexual Behavior, Volume 21, Number 3 / June, 1992</ref>
The pre-Taoist, pre-Confucian tradition of China was predominantly shamanistic, with the majority of shamans being female. Male same-sex love was believed to have originated in the mythical south, thus homosexuality is sometimes still called "Southern wind". From this period, numerous spirits or deities were associated with homosexuality, bisexuality and transgenderism. These include [[Chou Wang]], [[Lan Caihe]] - one of the [[Eight Immortals]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Eberhard|first=Wolfram|title=A Dictionary of Chinese Symbols: Hidden Symbols in Chinese Life and Thought|publisher=Routledge & Kegan Paul, London|year=1986|isbn=0-415-00228-1}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/journals/jras/1916-21.htm |title=The Eight Immortals |publisher=Sacred-texts.com |accessdate=2009-07-16}}</ref> [[Shan Gu]], and [[Yu the Great]], and [[Gun (Chinese)|Gun]].<ref>Conner & Sparks (1998), p. 12, "Chinese Shamanism..."</ref>
Religious Taoism is generally considered to be [[polytheism|polytheistic]]. Its many deities, although unified by the idea and practice of Tao, are often pictured as part of a heavenly hierarchy that mirrors the bureaucracy of [[Imperial era of Chinese history|Imperial China]]. According to the beliefs of Religious Taoism, Chinese deities may be promoted or demoted for their actions. Some deities are also simply exalted humans, such as [[Guan Yu]], the god of honor and piety. The particular deities worshipped vary according to geographical regions and historical periods in China, though the general pattern of worship is more constant.<ref>Maspero (1981), p. 92.</ref>
Sexual abstinence is seen as virtuous if it results from self-denial, allowing greater attention to spiritual or heroic matters. This is not the case if abstinence is the result of castration. [[Eunuch]]s in Chinese myths are usually portrayed as "greedy, temperamental and cowardly", with a similar lack of self-discipline as women.<ref name=Louie91>Louie (2002), p. 91</ref>
==Mythical lands== Women's Kingdom (or Women's Country) is a country situated in Southern Tibet or on an isolated Island. The island is believed to be inaccessible to normal travel due to its being surrounded by water of less-than-usual density, causing ships to sink. Occasional travellers have found themselves transported to the island by whirlwinds and reported that it is inhabited solely by women. These women have a fully functional community without men, and the only relationships are therefore between women. These women reproduce themselves by sleeping outdoors, where they become pregnant through the action of the southern wind blowing across their bodies, or by bathing in pools of water. Any male babies that are born die before the age of three.<ref>Werner (2008), p. 369, "Women's Kingdom"</ref><ref>Conner & Spark (1998), p. 349, "Women's Country".</ref>
Another Women's Kingdom exists in folklore. This is a mythical land, in which men and women have their social roles reversed. Men are called women, and run the household while wearing traditional women's clothes. Conversely, women dress in men's boots and hats and are in charge of public affairs. The folk belief in this Women's Kingdom is best known from the eighteenth-century novel ''Romance of the Flowers in the Mirror''.<ref>Conner & Spark (1998), p. 349, "Women's Kingdom".</ref> [[Image:Dragon gods - Project Gutenberg eText 15250.jpg|thumbnail|right|180px|Dragon-gods, from ''Myths and Legends of China'', 1922 by E. T. C. Werner. Dragons sometimes sexually assaulted older men.]]
==Supernatural encounters== Homosexual encounters are common in Chinese folk stories. The ''[[Xian (Taoism)|Xian]]'' (animal spirits or fairies) often choose same-sex partners, usually young men or boys.<ref name=GLBTQchinese2>Xiaomingxiong (2002), p.2</ref> Some stories show Xian asking the Lord of the Fairies permission to stay with their male lovers for some time, which could be as long as years, due to time's passing differently in the fairy realm. If the Lord of the Fairies remembers, he may cut the relationship short, hence such relationships are often short, with melancholic endings as the human participant is abandoned.<ref>Conner & Sparks (1998), p. 351, "Xian"</ref> A Xian-human relationship is seen in the tale of "The Scholar and the Flower Spirit".<ref>Conner & Sparks (1998), p. 297, "The Scholar and the Flower Spirit"</ref>
One exception to the age preference for younger men is shown by the [[dragon]], a powerful mythological beast, and a phallic symbol of male potency.<ref name=Louie25>Louie (2002), p. 25</ref> According to [[Xiaomingxiong]], [[Chinese dragons]] "consistently enjoy sexual relationships with older men", one example being in the tale of "Old Farmer and a Dragon", in which a sixty-year-old farmer is forcibly sodomised by a passing dragon, resulting in wounds from penetration and bites that require medical attention.<ref name=GLBTQchinese2/>
Other stories that feature homoerotic interactions or transgender figures include "The Farmer and the Pig" and "Fox Fairy and a Scholar".<ref name=GLBTQchinese3>Xiaomingxiong (2002), p.3</ref>
==Legendary figures and deities== [[Guan Yu]], the deified military leader, is described in legend as "unmoved by beautiful women".<ref name=Louie26>Louie (2002), p. 26</ref> This has been read as denoting asexuality by most commentators, rather than a homosexual subtext, but in folklore his relationships with his (not blood-related) brothers are assumed to have a homoerotic component.<ref name=Louie33>Louie (2002), p. 33</ref>
Although the literature of some taoist schools included homosexuality as one of the forms of sexual misconduct, [[Tu Er Shen]] is a deity in Chinese folklore who is popularly said to manage the love and sex between homosexual men. His name literally means "[[rabbit]] deity". According to "The Tale of the Rabbit God" in the ''[[Zi Bu Yu]]'', Tu Er Shen was originally a man called Hu Tianbao, who fell in love with a handsome young imperial inspector of the Fujian Province. One day Hu Tianbao was caught peeping on the inspector, at which point he confessed his reluctant affections for the other man. The imperial inspector had Hu Tianbao sentenced to death by beating. Since his crime was one of love, underworld officials decided to right the injustice by delegating Hu Tianbao as the god and safeguarder of homosexual affections.<ref>Szonyi, Michael "The Cult of Hu Tianbao and the Eighteenth-Century Discourse of Homosexuality." Late Imperial China - Volume 19, Number 1, June 1998, pp. 1-25, The Johns Hopkins University Press</ref> In order to cater to the needs of modern homosexuals, worship of the Rabbit God has been resuscitated in [[Taiwan]]: a temple was founded in [[Yonghe City]] by a gay, Taoist priest.<ref>"Taoist homosexuals turn to the Rabbit God: The Rabbit Temple in Yonghe enshrines a deity based on an historic figure that is believed to take care of homosexuals" by Ho Yi, staff reporter, ''Taipei Times,'' Sunday, October 21, 2007, Page 17 [http://www.taipeitimes.com/News/feat/archives/2007/10/21/2003384192]</ref> <ref>The Ultra Supreme Elder Lord's Scripture of Precepts(太上老君戒經), in "The Orthodox Tao Store"(正統道藏)</ref><ref>The Great Dictionary of Taoism"(道教大辭典), by Chinese Taoism Association, published in China in 1994, {{ISBN|7-5080-0112-5}}/B.054</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Mythology|LGBT}} {{colbegin}} * [[LGBT themes in mythology]] * [[LGBT themes in speculative fiction]] * [[LGBT literature]] * [[LGBT history]] * [[Transgender in China]] * [[Homosexuality in China]] *[[Religion and homosexuality]] *[[Religion and transgenderism]] {{colend}}

===General===
* {{cite book |title= Cassell's Encyclopedia of Queer Myth, Symbol and Spirit|last= Conner |first= Randy P. |authorlink= |author2=Sparks, David Hatfield |author3=Sparks, Mariya |year=1998 |publisher=Cassell |location=UK |isbn=0-304-70423-7}} * {{cite web|url=http://www.glbtq.com/literature/chinese_myth.html|title=GLBTQ Encyclopedia, "Chinese Mythology"|accessdate=2009-03-20|last=[[Xiaomingxiong]]|first=|year=2002|work=|publisher=New England Publishing Associates|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090709093905/http://www.glbtq.com/literature/chinese_myth.html|archivedate=2009-07-09|df=}} *{{cite book |title= Theorising Chinese masculinity: society and gender in China|last= Louie|first=Kam |authorlink= |year= 2002|publisher= Cambridge University Press|location= |isbn=978-0-521-80621-3}} *{{cite book |title= Myths and Legends of China|last= Werner|first= Edward T. C.|authorlink= |year=2008 |publisher=BiblioBazaar, LLC |location= |isbn=978-0-554-29643-2}}

{{Infobox library | library_name = Lilly Library | image = IUB Lilly Library P1000231.jpg | alt = an exterior photograph of the Lilly Library with the Showalter Fountain in the foreground | caption = The Lilly Library | location = [[Bloomington, Indiana]], [[United States|U.S.A.]] | coordinates = {{coord|39.1679|-86.5190|format=dms|region:US-IN_type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | established = {{start date and age|1960}} | num_branches = N/A | collection_size = Approximately 450,000 [[book]]s, 8.5 million [[manuscript]]s, 60,000 [[comic book]]s, 16,000 [[Miniature book|mini books]], 35,000 [[puzzle]]s, and 150,000 pieces of [[sheet music]].<ref name="The Lilly Library: The Collections">{{cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/collections.shtml|title=The Lilly Library: The Collections|accessdate=August 9, 2007|publisher=''Indiana University'' (Bloomington, Indiana)}}</ref> | annual_circulation = Library does not publicly circulate | pop_served = 48,514 faculty, staff, and students at [[Indiana University Bloomington]], additional scholars, and members of the public | director = Joel Silver | num_employees = 20 <ref>{{cite web|url=https://libraries.indiana.edu/staff/lilly-library|title=Lilly Library Staff|accessdate=April 20, 2018|publisher=''Indiana University'' (Bloomington, Indiana)}}</ref> | website = [http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/] }}
The '''Lilly Library''', located on the campus of [[Indiana University (Bloomington)|Indiana University]] in [[Bloomington, Indiana]], is an important rare book and manuscript library in the United States. At its dedication on October 3, 1960, the library contained a collection of 20,000 books, 17,000 manuscripts, more than fifty oil paintings, and 300 prints. Currently, the Lilly Library has 8.5 million manuscripts, 450,000 books, 60,000 comic books, 16,000 mini books, 35,000 puzzles, and 150,000 sheets of music.
==History== [[File:Atlas maior 1655 - vol 10 - Novus Atlas Sinensis - cover - P1080377.JPG|thumb|right|upright|''Novus Atlas Sinensis'' by [[Martino Martini]] from the collection of Lilly Library]] The Lilly Library was founded in 1960 with the collection of [[Josiah K. Lilly, Jr.]], owner of [[Eli Lilly and Company|Lilly Pharmaceuticals]] in [[Indianapolis]]. J.K. Lilly was a collector most of his life. From the mid-1920s until his death, he devoted a great deal of his leisure time to building his collections of books and manuscripts, works of art, coins, stamps, military miniatures, firearms and edged weapons, and nautical models. J. K. Lilly's collections of books and manuscripts, totaling more than 20,000 books and 17,000 manuscripts, together with more than fifty oil paintings and 300 prints, were given by the collector to Indiana University between 1954 and 1957. These materials form the foundation of the rare book and manuscript collections of the Lilly Library.
The extent to which J. K. Lilly realized his collecting goals was summed up by Frederick B. Adams, Jr., at the dedication of the Lilly Library on October 3, 1960: "Mr. Lilly's books cover so many fields that it is difficult to believe that any one man's enthusiasm could encompass them all. It is equally astounding that he was able to acquire so many books of such scarcity and quality in the short space of 30 years. Money alone isn't the answer; diligence, courage, and imagination were also essential. The famous books in English and American literature, the books most influential in American life, the great works in the history of science and ideas--all these are among the 20,000 Lilly books in this building."<ref>[http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/tour/foyer.shtml Indiana University; Lilly Library ]- Accessed 2012-01-08</ref>
==Collection== [[Image:Yale Dunlap Broadside.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Yale University's copy of the Dunlap broadside<ref>{{cite web|url=http://beinecke.library.yale.edu/dl_crosscollex/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080514205929/http://beinecke.library.yale.edu/dl_crosscollex/ |archivedate=2008-05-14 |df= }}</ref>]] The library now contains approximately 450,000 books, 8.5 million manuscripts, 60,000 comic books, 16,000 mini books, 35,000 puzzles, and 150,000 pieces of sheet music.<ref name="The Lilly Library: The Collections"/>
The library's holdings are particularly strong in British and American history and literature, Latin Americana, medicine and science, food and drink, children's literature, fine printing and binding, popular music, medieval and Renaissance manuscripts, and early printing.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://jama.ama-assn.org/content/237/26/2856.1.short|title=Notable Medical Books From the Lilly Library, Indiana University|accessdate=April 19, 2011|publisher=''The Journal of The American Medical Association''}}</ref> There are many notable items in the library's collections.
* New Testament of the [[Gutenberg Bible]] * The first printed collection of Shakespeare's works (the [[First Folio]]) * [[John James Audubon|Audubon's]] [[Birds of America (book)|Birds of America]] * One of 26 extant copies of the "First Printing of the Declaration of Independence" (also known as the "[[Dunlap Broadside]]") that was printed in Philadelphia on July 4, 1776 * [[George Washington]]'s letter accepting the presidency of the United States * [[Abraham Lincoln]]'s desk from his law office and a leaf from the famous Abraham Lincoln "Sum Book" ca. 1824-1826 * [[Philip Dormer Stanhope, 4th Earl of Chesterfield|Lord Chesterfield's]] letters to his son * The manuscripts of Robert Burns's "[[Auld Lang Syne]]" * The [[Boxer Codex]], manuscript written c. 1595 which contains illustrations of ethnic groups in the [[Philippines]] at the time of their initial contact with the [[Spaniards]]. * J. M. Synge's "[[The Playboy of the Western World]]" * J. M. Barrie's "[[Peter Pan]]" * Typescripts of many of [[Ian Fleming]]'s [[James Bond]] novels
The library also owns the papers of Hollywood directors [[Orson Welles]] and [[John Ford]], film critic [[Pauline Kael]], the poets [[Sylvia Plath]] and [[Ezra Pound]], and authors [[Edith Wharton]] and [[Upton Sinclair]].
=== Ruth E. Adomeit collection ===
After the death of [[Ruth E. Adomeit]] in 1996, her collection of [[miniature book]]s was donated to the Lilly. The Adomeit collection is considered to be one of the largest collections of miniature books. The collection is titled '''''4000 Years of Miniature Books'''''.<ref>[http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/miniatures/adomeit.shtml 4000 Years of Miniature Books]- Retrieved 2012-01-08</ref>
The Adomeit collection ranges the entire history of human record keeping in miniature form, from cuneiform tablets of circa 2000 B.C. to contemporary small press and artists' books.
=== Michael E. Uslan Collection === [[Michael Uslan]], producer of the Batman movies, donated over 30,000 comics to the Lilly Library. Parts of the collection were displayed at the Lilly Library in an exhibition called "Comics as Cultural Mythology: The Michael E. Uslan Collection of Comic Books and Graphic Novels" from September 12, 2005 to December 17, 2005.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://newsinfo.iu.edu/news-archive/2406.html|title=Comics as culture? Holy textbook, Batman!|last=|first=|date=|website=newsinfo.iu.edu|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2015-10-19}}</ref>
The Uslan Collection also contains a vast array of action figures<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/shorttitle/actionfigures.html|title=Michael E. Uslan Collection. Action figures, 1990-2006|website=www.indiana.edu|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> as well as other pop culture memorabilia,<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/shorttitle/uslanmisc.html|title=Michael E. Uslan Collection. Popular culture collectibles, 1966-2010|website=www.indiana.edu|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> which can be accessed through the Lilly Library Request System.
The collection is currently housed at the Auxiliary Library Facility (ALF) and can be accessed for use through IUCAT, the Indiana University Library catalog.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Michael E. Uslan Collection; Special Databases: The Collections: The Lilly Library: Indiana University Bloomington|url = http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/dbs/comic.shtml|website = www.indiana.edu|accessdate = 2015-10-19}}</ref>
=== Jerry Slocum Mechanical Puzzle Collection === In 2006, the library received a collection of 30,000 mechanical puzzles and 4,000 puzzle related books from [[Jerry Slocum]].<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2006/07/25/science/25puzz.html ''The New York Times'', "Celebrating Puzzles, in 18,446,744,073,709,551,616 Moves (or So)", July 25, 2006]</ref> The collection is the largest assemblage of its kind in the world. Mechanical puzzles are hand-held objects that must be manipulated to solve the puzzle. The collection spans multiple centuries and five continents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/collections/overview/puzzles.shtml|title=Slocum Puzzle Collection: Guide to the Collections: The Lilly Library: Indiana UniversityBloomington|website=www.indiana.edu|access-date=2018-04-05}}</ref>
The collection is on permanent display in the Slocum Puzzle Room and includes puzzles that can be handled by visitors. The Lilly Library is currently developing an [http://webapp1.dlib.indiana.edu/images/splash.htm?scope=lilly/slocum online database] of the collection.
=== French Revolution Documents === The Lilly contains an extensive collection of material that centers on the French Revolution of 1789. The collection contains approximately seven thousand pieces and includes all types of printed materials, such as journals, polemical pamphlets, and many other documents. The collection consists of 3,362 legal publications. The majority of the other documents are royal and administrative acts published in pamphlet form between 1789 and 1799. There are royal edicts, arrets, addresses, declarations, reglements, lettres patentes, rapports, ordonnances, memoires, lois, and various other titled or untitled official documents.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/french-about.shtml|title=French Revolution Documents: Special databases: The Collections: The Lilly Library: Indiana University Bloomington|website=www.indiana.edu|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref>
=== Bernardo Mendel Collection === The Mendel collection is divided into two categories: one relates to the period of geographical discovery and exploration and the other consists of additions made by the Lilly Library after the original acquisition. The geographical and discovery collection ranges from the 15th through the 19th century. It includes the great cosmographic and geographic works of Ptolemy as well as narratives of the discovery and conquest of the New World. The emphasis of the subsequent acquisitions is on Latin Americana from the 17th through the 19th century, with particular attention to Mexican history.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/etexts/mendel/|title=The Bernardo Mendel Collection: an exhibit: a machine-readable transcription|publisher=Lilly Library (Indiana University, Bloomington)|date=2004-06-01|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref>
The Mendel Room in the Lilly was dedicated in 1964.<ref name=":0" />
=== James Whitcomb Riley Collection === The Lilly Library has the personal papers of [[James Whitcomb Riley]] in a variety of manuscript collections. There are also miscellaneous uncataloged materials that includes clippings, scrapbooks, photographs, memorabilia, and other ephemera. The majority of his writings and personal correspondence are found in the Riley mss. Hundreds of Riley’s books are listed in Indiana University’s online catalog.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/collections/overview/riley.shtml|title=The Collections: Guide to the Collecti++ons: James Whitcomb Riley (1849-1916)}}</ref> On the 150th anniversary of his birth, the library produced an online exhibition that explores James Whitcomb Riley’s impact on American society and the 19th century literary world.
The Lilly Library has other Indiana authors in their collection as well.
===Film, Radio & Television Collection=== The Lilly Library houses 2,000 motion picture scripts, including the second draft script for the film [[Chariots of Fire]]. In order to supplement the script material the library added to the collection material from [[Orson Welles]], [[John Ford]], [[Clifford Odets]], and most recently [[Peter Bogdanovich]]. The library is home to 800 BBC radio scripts and the papers of [[Lance Sieveking]] and [[D. G. Bridson]]. The television scripts consist mostly of material from [[John McGreevey]] as well as scripts from such television shows as [[Star Trek: The Original Series]] and [[Mission: Impossible (TV series)]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/collections/overview/film.shtml | title=Film, Radio & Television | publisher=The Lilly Library}}</ref> *The [[John Ford]] Collection includes four of his Oscars - one which is on display - stills from Ben-Hur (1925), script drafts, and correspondence.<ref>https://libraries.indiana.edu/oscar</ref>
===Sheet Music=== The library houses 150,000 pieces of sheet music. The prominent collections are the Sam DeVincent Collection of American Sheet Music, the Starr Sheet Music Collection, and the Wildermuth Collection of [[Hoagy Carmichael]] Sheet Music.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/collections/sheetmusic.shtml | title=The Collections: Sheet Music | publisher=The Lilly Library}}</ref>
===Dale Messick Collection=== The library has the original pen and ink drawings from [[Dale Messick]]'s comic [[Brenda Starr]]. The collection is organized and searchable by date.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/collections/overview/messick.shtml | title=Dale Messick Collection | publisher=The Lilly Library}}</ref>
===Mystery Writers of America Collection=== The material is made up of papers relating to meetings, correspondence, drafts, conferences, periodicals and books from the [[Mystery Writers of America]] association.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/collections/overview/mwa.shtml | title=Mystery Writers of America | publisher=The Lilly Library}}</ref>
===Plath Manuscript Collection=== The library has 94 poems as well as 3,324 examples of correspondence, writing, and memorabilia from [[Sylvia Plath]]. The poems are arranged in chronological order and the miscellaneous items are organized by type. 150 books from Plath's only library are housed at the Lilly Library as well.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/guides/plath/sylvia.shtml | title=Sylvia Plath Manuscript Collection | publisher=The Lilly Library}}</ref>
==Other collections==
* American animator [[Willis Pyle]], known for his work on ''[[Pinocchio (1940 film)|Pinocchio]]'' and ''[[Mr. Magoo]]'', donated his personal archives and papers to the Lilly Library.<ref name="thr">{{cite news|first=Mike |last=Barnes |title=Willis Pyle, Famed Animator on 'Pinocchio' and 'Mr. Magoo,' Dies at 101 |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/willis-pyle-dead-pinocchio-magoo-900742 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |date=2016-06-08 |accessdate=2016-06-28}}</ref> * [[Peter and Iona Opie]] donated their collection of approximately 1,200 children's books to the Lilly. Peter and Iona Opie are the authors of ''The Oxford Dictionary of Nursery Rhymes'' (1952) and ''The Lore and Language of Schoolchildren'' (1959).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/shorttitle/opie.html|title=The Peter & Iona Opie Collection of Folklore and Related Topics IU Lilly Library|last=|first=|date=|website=www.indiana.edu|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> * The Gosling Mandrovsky Playing Card Collection<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/dbs/gosling-cards.shtml|title=The Gosling Playing Cards Collection: Special Databases: The Collections: The Lilly Library: Indiana University Bloomington|website=www.indiana.edu|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref> * [[Richard Hughes (British writer)|Richard Hughes]], author of ''[[A High Wind in Jamaica (novel)|A High Wind in Jamaica]]''. * 398 books and periodicals from the collection of Elizabeth Gamble Miller<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/dbs/millerbooks.shtml|title=Elizabeth Gamble Miller Collection: Special databases: The Collections: The Lilly Library: Indiana University Bloomington|website=www.indiana.edu|access-date=2018-04-19}}</ref>
== Library location == The Lilly Library is located on the southern side of a small square in the heart of the Indiana University Bloomington campus. Showalter Fountain is in the middle of the square. [[Indiana University Art Museum]] and Indiana University School of Fine Arts are on the opposite (northern) side of the square. Indiana University Auditorium is on the square's eastern side.<ref>Any IUB campus map, or Google Maps</ref>
== Lilly Library at Duke University == The Perkins System Libraries, of [[Duke University Libraries]], contains the ''Lilly Library''. This was formerly the Trinity Library, and then the East campus Library. In 1990 [[Ruth Lilly]], daughter of Josiah K. Lilly, Jr., made a substantial donation to Duke University and the library was renamed.<ref>[http://library.duke.edu/about/history.html Duke University; Lilly Library]- Retrieved 2012-01-08</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Library and information science}} *[[David A. Randall]]
==References== [[File:Escalante-Lilly-p61verso-62.jpg|thumb|The Lilly Library copy of the ''Discurso de navegacion...'' by [[Bernardino de Escalante]] (1577), one of the first European books to contain (an attempt to reproduce) Chinese characters. The book is very rare; the preface of a 1958 Spanish reprint states that it was not available in the National Library of Spain in Madrid, and a photocopy had to be obtained from the [[British Museum]]]] <references/>
==External links== *[http://newsinfo.iu.edu/asset/page/normal/5483.html Video Tour of the Lilly Library] *[http://www.indiana.edu/~liblilly/index.php Lilly Library]
{{IUB}}
